channel.title: Interleaved RSS Feed
channel.description: This is an interleaved feed of the most recent entries from each RSS source, skipping any feeds with errors.

item.title: What to know about the inflation report.
item.description: Federal Reserve policymakers are expected to cut interest rates at their meeting next month, but they will be watching fresh inflation data ahead of the decision.

item.title: Portraits of Survival: The Israeli Hostages Who Made It Home
item.description: They are now trying to rebuild their lives, campaign for the return of the hostages still in Gaza and mourn for those who were killed.

item.title: London locals go to war with upmarket British bakery chain Gail’s over gentrification and its right-leaning chairman
item.description: Hundreds of people have signed a petition trying to block a new Gail's in Walthamstow, namechecking its divisive chairman.

item.title: Thai Court Ejects Prime Minister From Office, as Old Guard Reasserts Power
item.description: Prime Minister Srettha Thavisin was considered a figurehead leader in a behind-the-scenes power struggle. He was ousted on ethics charges.

item.title: Middle East Crisis: Palestinian Authority Leader’s Visit Highlights Turkey’s Unique Role in Gaza Conflict
item.description: Turkish officials have bashed Israel and praised Hamas, complicating their country’s place in diplomacy aimed at ending the war.

item.title: The ‘sustainability recession’ will end soon—and not by choice
item.description: It’s possible that most of the ESG pullback is for show—a reverse form of virtue signaling.

item.title: Ukraine’s Incursion Into Russia: What to Know
item.description: The incursion caught Russia by surprise and signified a shift in tactics for Kyiv after more than two years of war with Russia.

item.title: Thai Court Ejects Prime Minister From Office, as Old Guard Reasserts Power
item.description: Prime Minister Srettha Thavisin was considered a figurehead leader in a behind-the-scenes power struggle. He was ousted on ethics charges.

item.title: Montana governor raked in more than $23 million in income over four years
item.description: Most of Greg Gianforte’s income since 2019 came from profits on investments, his tax returns indicate. He is paid about $120,000 a year for being governor.

item.title: The Global Race to Control A.I.
item.description: We explore who is winning — and what could come next.

item.title: Ukraine’s Incursion Into Russia: What to Know
item.description: The incursion caught Russia by surprise and signified a shift in tactics for Kyiv after more than two years of war with Russia.

item.title: X ordered to pay €550,000 to Irish employee fired for not replying to Elon Musk’s yes-or-resign ‘extremely hardcore’ ultimatum
item.description: It is the largest sum the agency has ever awarded.

item.title: Russia Moves Some Troops From Ukraine to Fight Incursion, Kyiv and U.S. Say
item.description: Ukraine hopes that such a move will relieve pressure on frontline units. But Moscow appears reluctant to withdraw troops from eastern Ukraine, where it has been steadily advancing.

item.title: Russia Moves Some Troops From Ukraine to Fight Incursion, Kyiv and U.S. Say
item.description: Ukraine hopes that such a move will relieve pressure on frontline units. But Moscow appears reluctant to withdraw troops from eastern Ukraine, where it has been steadily advancing.

item.title: Bluetongue virus cases are soaring in Europe—these are the symptoms to look out for
item.description: Bluetongue is a non-contagious, insect-borne viral disease that affects ruminants such as sheep and cows but not pigs or horses.
